title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.14.1 - 3 | 6-11-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurunmelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: No, the sequence of description in the Bhagavatam follows the questions and answers, the questions and the answers.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces Chapter 14 of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining that the Bhagavatam's structure is based on questions and answers rather than strict chronological order, emphasizing the importance of the message.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna went to Dvaraka to see Lord Krishna and other friends and also to learn from the Lord of his next activities.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to explain the first verse of the chapter, focusing on Arjuna's visit to Dvaraka to see Lord Krishna and inquire about his future plans.

segments.key_quote: His devotees they simply follow the Lord they have no other engagement they simply want to please Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the first verse, explaining Yudhishthira's perfect rule and Arjuna's role as a devotee seeking Krishna's next program, highlighting the devotee's desire to please Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Maharaja Yudhishthira then began to observe some inauspicious omens which were fearful in themselves.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the second verse, describing Yudhishthira's observation of inauspicious omens upon Arjuna's delayed return, and begins to explain Srila Prabhupada's purport on the verse.

segments.key_quote: billions of suns are created by Krishna and he only annihilates everything and everything all his creation and destruction happens within one breathing period of the incarnation of Krishna called Maha Vishnu.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain Srila Prabhupada's purport on the second verse, describing the power of Krishna and Maha Vishnu, and the importance of the sun for material prosperity.

segments.key_quote: Maharaja Yudhishthira observed some discrepancies in his kingdom.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain the second verse, focusing on Yudhishthira's observation of discrepancies in his kingdom and his suspicion of Krishna's disappearance.

segments.key_quote: He saw that the direction of eternal time had changed and this was very fearful.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the third verse, describing Yudhishthira's observation of changes in time, seasonal irregularities, and negative qualities in people.

segments.key_quote: when civilization disconnected from the loving relation of the Supreme Personality of Godhead symptoms like changes of seasonal regulations foul means of livelihood greed anger and fraudulence become rampant
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport on the third verse, emphasizing the connection between a civilization's disconnection from God and the rise of negative qualities and irregularities in nature.

segments.key_quote: Elsewhere in the Bhagavatam it is said one who is not a devotee of the Supreme Lord he cannot have any good qualities, he may appear to be very nice man but that so called nice man inside his heart full of all dirty things.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain Srila Prabhupada's purport, stating that a non-devotee cannot possess good qualities, regardless of outward appearances.

segments.key_quote: but Maharaja Yudhishthira was astonished to experience even a slight change in the godly atmosphere of his kingdom
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain Srila Prabhupada's purport, describing how godless people will use any means to earn a living, and how Yudhishthira's observation of even slight changes led him to suspect Krishna's disappearance.

segments.key_quote: To remain free from all these bad qualities is to be Krishna conscious. And there is no other way.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes the explanation of the third verse, defining foul means of livelihood as deviation from one's prescribed duty and emphasizing Krishna consciousness as the only way to remain free from negative qualities.
